questions.text: A 14-year-old female came in with irritation in the eyes, loss of vision and hazy cornea. Her symptoms began 9 days ago and have been gradually progressive thus prompting her to consult. On examination you notice the cornea is hazy with a steamy surface, giving a general ground glass appearance. The iris is dimly visible. The examination findings are shown below. Her previous medical history is significant for hearing loss and vertigo. Which of the following statements is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: After the disease has reached its peak, the cornea clears slowly from the margin towards the centre, which may remain hazy for a long time but finally improves except in the worst cases

options.label: B
options.text: Syphilis should be ruled out in this patient

options.label: C
options.text: Local treatment in the form of lubricants, topical steroids and cycloplegics to control the uveitis is helpful in the acute stage

options.label: D
options.text: The slit lamp shows thickening of the cornea and often folds of the Descemet's membrane and an immune ring of the Wessely type

questions.correct_answer: D. The slit lamp shows thickening of the cornea and often folds of the Descemet's membrane and an immune ring of the Wessely type
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The slit lamp shows thickening of the cornea and often folds of the Descemet's membrane and an immune ring of the Wessely type The given case points towards the diagnosis of interstitial keratitis most probably as a manifestation of Cogan’s syndrome . Cogan syndrome: Interstitial keratitis and deafness (Cogan syndrome) is a rare disease affecting young adults. The keratitis is associated with vertigo, tinnitus and deafness. This describes disciform keratitis. This disease is characterized by the gradual appearance of a central grey disc lying in the middle layers of the stroma, usually with a denser central opacity.

Highyeild:

The slit lamp shows thickening of the cornea and often folds of the Descemet’s membrane and an immune ring of the Wessely type.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. After slight irritative symptoms with some ciliary congestion, one or more hazy patches appear in the deep layers of the cornea near the margin or towards the centre. If they start near the margin, they migrate towards the centre, until finally, the whole cornea looks lustreless and dull. In 2–4 weeks, the whole cornea is hazy with a steamy surface , giving a general ground glass appearance in which denser spots can always be seen. After the disease has reached its peak, the cornea clears slowly from the margin towards the centre, which may remain hazy for a long time but finally improves except in the worst cases. Option: B. Interstitial keratitis due to inherited syphilis most commonly affects children between the ages of 5 and 15 years. Diagnosis of interstitial keratitis depends on other evidence of congenital syphilis and positive serological reactions. Due to the pediatric age of this patient and syphilis being one of the most common causes of interstitial keratitis, the clinician should make a point to rule out the effect of inherited syphilis. Option: C. It is doubtful if antisyphilitic remedies have any influence over the course of the keratitis, partly because the cornea is nonvascular and partly because the reaction is probably largely allergic. It is possible, however, that intensive systemic treatment with penicillin may shorten the course of the disease. Local treatment in the form of lubricants, topical steroids and cycloplegics to control the uveitis is helpful in the acute stage. In the later stages , the best results are obtained by corneal grafting of the penetrating type , which generally has a good prognosis.

Extraedge:

Cogan syndrome. This consists of interstitial keratitis, vertigo and hearing loss. The interstitial keratitis usually begins in the peripheral cornea with round, white stromal opacities. It is important to recognize this diagnosis because early treatment with systemic corticosteroids may prevent permanent hearing loss. Approximately 10% of patients with Cogan syndrome have evidence of a systemic vasculitis. (Source: From Jay H. Krachmer, David A. Palay, eds. Cornea Atlas. 3rd ed. London: Saunders; 2014. pp. 221-223.)

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the given Image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hertel's exophthalmometer An Exophthalmometer is an instrument used for measuring the degree of forward displacement of the eye in exophthalmos. The device allows measurement of the forward distance of the lateral orbital rim to the front of the cornea.

Highyeild:

Exophthalmometers can also identify enophthalmos (retraction of the eye into the orbit), a sign of blow-out fracture or certain neoplasms .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Castroviejo caliper Option: B. Corneal trephine Option: D. Schiotz tonometer

Extraedge:

Exophthalmometer consists of a prism bar with millimetre markers on one surface and a view of the corneal surface on the other.

questions.text: On performing retinoscopy using a plane mirror in a patient who has a refractive error of -3D sphere with -2 cylinder at 90 degrees from a distance of 1 m, the reflex would move:

options.label: A
options.text: With the movement in the horizontal axis and against the movement in the vertical axis

options.label: B
options.text: With the movement in both the eyes

options.label: C
options.text: Against the movement in both the axes

options.label: D
options.text: With the movement in the vertical axis and against the movement in the horizontal axis

questions.correct_answer: C. Against the movement in both the axes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Against the movement in both the axes 3 D sphere when added to -2 D at 0° results in a horizontal meridian more than a horizontal meridian Hence it's regular astigmatism against the rule.

Highyeild:

Astigmatism is a common and generally treatable imperfection in the curvature of the eye that causes blurred distant and near vision. Astigmatism may be present from birth or it may develop after an eye injury, disease or surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. With the movement in the horizontal axis and against the movement in the vertical axis - no, option C is the correct statement. Option: B. With the movement in both eyes- no, option C is the correct statement. Option: D. With the movement in the vertical axis and against the movement in the horizontal axis- no, option C is the correct statement.

questions.text: Indocyanine green Angiography (ICG Angiography) is most useful in detecting?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occult Choroidal Neovascularization (Occult CNV) Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) involves the growth of new blood vessels that originate from the choroid through a break in the Bruch membrane into the sub-retinal pigment epithelium (sub-RPE) or subretinal pace. CNV is a major cause of visual loss.

Highyeild:

FA was once an essential tool in diagnosing and managing CNV . Spectral-domain OCT has largely replaced FA as the imaging modality of choice in the management of CNV. Angiographic patterns that have been described for CNV include the following:

questions.text: The image shown below is the procedure of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinoscopy The procedure of retinoscopy : The patient is made to sit at a distance of 1 m from the examiner ‘With the help of a retinoscope, light is thrown onto the patient's eye, who is instructed to look at a far point (to relax the accommodation). However, when a cycloplegic has been used, the patient can look directly into the light and have the refraction assessed along the actual visual axis. Through a hole in the retinoscope's mirror , the examiner observes a red reflex in the pupillary area of the patient. Then, the retinoscope is moved in horizontal and vertical meridian keeping a watch on the red reflex (which also moves when the retinoscope is moved).

Highyeild:

Optics of Retinoscope : Detailed optics of retinoscopy can be considered into three stages : Illumination stage Reflex stage Projection stage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Gonioscopy Option: C. Slit lamp procedure Option: D. Keratometer

Extraedge:

Types of Retinoscope: Reflecting (mirror retinoscope) Self illuminated retinoscope spot retinoscope Streak retinoscope

questions.text: Ravi, a 2-year-old boy, is taken to an ophthalmologist for a retinoscopy examination. Ophthalmologists administer cycloplegic before doing retinoscopy. Which is the cycloplegic administered to Ravi?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropine Atropine is indicated in children below the age of 5 years. It is used as 1% ointment thrice daily for 3. consecutive days before performing retinoscopy . Its effect lasts for 10 to 20 days .

Highyeild:

Atropine, considered the Gold Standard cycloplegic agent for refraction in children, has a long duration of action and more side effects as compared to short-acting cycloplegic agents.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Homatropine is used as 2% drops . One drop is often instilled every 10 minutes for 6 times and the retinoscopy is performed after 1 to 2 hours . Its effect lasts for 48 to 72 hours. It is used for most hypermetropic individuals between 5 and 25 years of age. Option: C . One drop of cyclopentolate is instilled after every 10-15 minutes 3 times (Havener's recommended dose) and the retinoscopy is performed about 60 to 90 min . later (after estimating the residual accommodation which should not exceed one dioptre). Option: D. Cyclopentolate is a short-acting cycloplegic. Its effect lasts for 6 to 18 hours . It is used as 1% eyedrops in patients between 8 and 20 years of age.

Extraedge:

Side Effects of Atropine : Ocular side effects - Allergic contact dermatitis of the lids, allergic conjunctivitis, keratitis and increase in intraocular pressure. Systemic side effects - dryness of secretions, tachycardia, fever, convulsions and possibly death

questions.text: Ophthalmologist was teaching undergraduates about wet retinoscopy in the OPD. Wet retinoscopy in the above statement refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: It's applying cycloplegics on the mirrors of the retinoscope before doing the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: instilling of cycloplegics in eyes before retinoscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Diluting cycloplegics in water is called wet retinoscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Using concentrated ointments is called wet retinoscopy

questions.correct_answer: B. instilling of cycloplegics in eyes before retinoscopy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

instilling of cycloplegics in eyes before retinoscopy Cycloplegics are the drugs which cause paralysis of accommodation and dilate the pupil (cycloplegia). These are used for retinoscopy when the examiner says that accommodation is abnormally active and will hinder the exact retinoscopy. Such a situation is encountered in young children and hypermetrope. When retinoscopy is performed after instilling cycloplegic drugs it is termed as wet retinoscopy in converse to dry retinoscopy (without cycloplegics).

Highyeild:

Prerequisite for retinoscopy - 1.Darkroom preferably 6 m long , or which can be converted into 6 m by use of a plane mirror. 2. Trial box containing spherical and cylindrical lenses of variable plus and minus powers, a pinhole, an occluder and prisms. 3. Trial frame preferably of adjustable type which can be used in children as well as in adults. 4. Vision box. A Snellen's self-illuminated vision box 5. Retinoscope . It is a simple device to perform the retinoscopy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . It's applying cycloplegics on the mirrors of the retinoscope before doing the procedure - this is not wet microscopy. Option: C . Diluting cycloplegics in water is called wet retinoscopy - this is not the correct option. Option: D . Using concentrated ointments is called wet retinoscopy - this is not the definition of wet microscopy.

Extraedge:

Atropine considered the Gold Standard cycloplegic agent for refraction in children, has a long duration of action and more side effects as compared to short-acting cycloplegic agents.

questions.text: A third-year resident while using a retinoscope found that he could not see red reflex due to hazy media and high refractive error. How can he overcome this difficulty? a) By using mydriatic b) By converging light using a convex lens c) By using miotic d) By converging lens using a concave lens. Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only a,d Option: A. Red reflex may not be visible or may be poor. This may happen with small pupils, hazy media and a high degree of refractive error. In most cases, this difficulty is overcome by causing mydriasis and/or the use of converging light with a concave mirror retinoscope. Changing retinoscopy findings are observed due to abnormally active accommodation and are corrected by the use of cycloplegia. Option: D. Conflicting shadows moving in various directions in different parts of the pupillary area are seen in patients with irregular astigmatism .

Highyeild:

Optics of Retinoscope: Detailed optics of retinoscopy can be considered into three stages : Illumination stage Reflex stage Projection stage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. Scissors shadows may sometimes be seen in patients with regular astigmatism with dilated pupils. Mostly, this difficulty is diminished with the undilated pupil.

Extraedge:

Types of Retinoscope: Reflecting (mirror retinoscope) Self illuminated retinoscope spot retinoscope Streak retinoscope

questions.text: Given below are the images of the red reflex during retinoscopy. Image A indicates?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neutralisation point Depending upon the movement of the red reflex when a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter the results are interpreted as Neutralization point Neutralization When the red reflex moves with or against the movement of the retinoscope we do not exactly know the amount of refractive error. However, when the red glow in the pupil does not move then we know for certain that the patient has myopia of 1D.

Highyeild:

To estimate the degree of refractive error , the movement of the red reflex is neutralized by the addition of increasingly convex (+) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving with the movement of the plane mirror) or concave (-) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving against the movement of the plane mirror). When a simple spherical error alone is present, the movements of the red reflex will be neutralized in both vertical as well as horizontal meridian.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. With the movement of the red reflex along the movement of the retinoscope, indicates either emmetropia or hypermetropia or myopia of less than ID. Option: B . Against movement of the red reflex to the movement of the retinoscope implies myopia of more than ID. Option: C . However, in the presence of an astigmatic refractive error , one meridian is neutralized by adding an appropriate cylindrical lens with its axis at a right angle to the meridian to be neutralized. It is important to note that sometimes, especially, when the pupil is dilated, two light reflexes-one central and other peripheral may be seen. Under such circumstances, one should neutralize the central glow because the central parts of the cornea and lens are more important in forming the image on the retina.

Extraedge:

Types of Retinoscope: Reflecting (mirror retinoscope) Self-illuminated retinoscope spot retinoscope Streak retinoscope
